title: The Class Blueprint
subtitle: Creating Your Own Classes
description:
# Forging Your Own Classes

Now that you understand how to use classes, it's time to create your own! You'll design a complete character class from scratch.

## Creating a Class

A class defines a custom type with properties:

```csharp
public class Character
{
    public string Name { get; set; }
    public int Level { get; set; }
    public int Health { get; set; }
    public string CharacterClass { get; set; }
}
```

## Using Your Custom Class

```csharp
Character hero = new Character
{
    Name = "Valor",
    Level = 1,
    Health = 100,
    CharacterClass = "Warrior"
};

Console.WriteLine($"{hero.Name} is a level {hero.Level} {hero.CharacterClass}");
```

## Multiple Objects

You can create multiple objects from the same class:

```csharp
Character hero1 = new Character { Name = "Aria", Level = 5 };
Character hero2 = new Character { Name = "Valor", Level = 3 };
```

## Your Quest

1. Create a class called `Item` with these properties:
   - `string Name`
   - `string Type`
   - `int Value`
   - `int Weight`
2. Create two Item objects:
   - A sword: name "Iron Sword", type "Weapon", value 50, weight 10
   - A potion: name "Health Potion", type "Consumable", value 25, weight 2
3. Print information about both items
4. Calculate and print the total value and total weight
hints: Define the Item class with public class Item { } and add properties inside
Each property should be: public Type PropertyName { get; set; }
Create objects with object initializer syntax: new Item { Name = ..., Type = ... }
Access properties with dot notation to calculate totals
Use string interpolation with $"..." for formatted output
